message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by group A Streptococcus, which is associated with the release of streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B. The other options are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B (SPEB) is most commonly associated with necrotizing fasciitis. The fact that the patient has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus also increases the risk of necrotizing fasciitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is often caused by group A Streptococcus, and the exotoxin most commonly associated with this disease is Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B (SPEB).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by Group A streptococcus, and the most likely exotoxin associated with this presentation is Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is often caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, and the exotoxin most commonly associated with this condition is Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B. Diphtheria toxin causes diphtheria, Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin A is associated with toxic shock syndrome, and TSST-1 is also associated with toxic shock syndrome but is not commonly associated with necrotizing fasciitis.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by Group A Streptococcus, which produces Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is commonly caused by group A streptococcus, and one of the virulence factors produced by this bacterium is streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by Group A Streptococcus, which produces Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B (SPEB) that can cause tissue destruction and inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by group A Streptococcus, which produces the exotoxin Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B. The other options are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Necrotizing fasciitis is commonly caused by group A Streptococcus, which produces Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B, leading to tissue destruction and skin breakdown. Diphtheria toxin causes a different disease (diphtheria), while Streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin A and TSST-1 are associated with toxic shock syndrome.
